topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny introduces Brian Tolkin’s background (early Uber employee, ops-to-product path, uberPOOL, product ops) and previews topics like product+ops, product reviews, and jobs-to-be-done.

topics.title: How ops experience shapes product leadership
topics.summary: Brian explains how working in ops builds deep business understanding and customer closeness, which later informs scalable product decisions and better prioritization.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor messages for Pendo (product experience platform) and Explo (embedded analytics).

topics.title: Product vs ops tension and mutual respect
topics.summary: They discuss why product teams can undervalue ops, and Brian frames product+ops as complementary “twin engines,” with ops providing fast iteration and rich qualitative insights from the field.

topics.title: Origin and purpose of product operations
topics.summary: Brian defines product operations at Uber as strengthening the bidirectional feedback loop between centralized product teams and globally distributed ops teams, helping ship features globally and bring market insights back.

topics.title: Early Uber surge pricing: humans in loop
topics.summary: Brian describes how surge pricing was initially controlled by city GMs (on/off windows, caps, geographies) due to local knowledge, risk, and technical constraints before full automation.

topics.title: Scaling war stories: UberX name and China launch
topics.summary: Brian shares early Uber anecdotes: UberX’s name started as a placeholder, and the stressful overnight scramble to launch uberPOOL in Chengdu, China, culminating in a memorable post-launch breakfast.

topics.title: Opendoor’s COVID pivot to virtual processes
topics.summary: Brian recounts Opendoor temporarily stopping home buying when COVID hit, then using the pause to virtualize key parts of the process to operate safely and continue serving customers.

topics.title: What Opendoor does: simple home selling
topics.summary: Brian explains Opendoor’s core product: sellers enter home info online and receive an all-cash offer, enabling a simple, certain sale with flexible closing and minimal hassle.

topics.title: Making product and ops work together
topics.summary: Brian outlines lessons: mutual respect, focusing scarce engineering on highest-leverage systems, being explicit about what won’t be built yet, and designing for real-world messiness and non-deterministic human behavior.

topics.title: From doing things manually to scaling with tech
topics.summary: Using driver onboarding as an example, Brian describes the evolution from 1:1 onboarding to classes to video, then to automation (e.g., OCR/verification), freeing ops capacity to tackle new problems.

topics.title: How to run effective product reviews
topics.summary: Brian shares product review principles: align on goals (accountability + making the product better), avoid “firing squad” dynamics through probing and context-sharing, keep meetings small (<10), and rely on reusable artifacts.

topics.title: Jobs-to-be-done at Opendoor in practice
topics.summary: Brian explains why JTBD helps at Opendoor (infrequent customer journeys, complex context), how it’s embedded in product review templates and culture, and why correct adoption requires time and non-dogmatic thinking.

topics.title: Experimentation with low volume and intuition
topics.summary: Brian discusses A/B testing constraints with low sample sizes: run power analyses, accept long runtimes when necessary, use alternative methods (observational data, geo comparisons, lower confidence thresholds), and ship with judgment plus feedback loops.

topics.title: Zillow competition and partnership setup
topics.summary: They begin discussing Zillow’s attempt to compete with Opendoor and the later partnership; Brian frames the partnership as a synergy between Zillow’s audience reach and Opendoor’s transaction capabilities.
